filteredArticles.headline: Rev. Al Sharpton calls for minority representation, transparency in management of endowment
filteredArticles.abstract: Sharpton asked Gutmann to publish a report on the involvement of African American professionals in the management of Penn’s $14.7 billion endowment.

dominantMedia.content: Activist Reverend Al Sharpton is president of National Action Network, which is calling for universities to be more transparent in the demographic data of their asset managers. (Photo by Gerard Flynn | CC BY 2.0)

filteredArticles.headline: Penn outlines four possible scenarios for fall 2020, will finalize plan by end of June
filteredArticles.abstract: The four scenarios include a hybrid of in-person and online instruction, a shortened in-person semester, more robust summer 2021 course offerings, and entirely online learning.
filteredArticles.infobox:

dominantMedia.title: Fall semester Locust Walk
dominantMedia.content: Penn will make a decision on the outcome of the fall semester by the end of June.

filteredArticles.headline: Over 200 profs. sign letter demanding U. use endowment to protect grad students
filteredArticles.abstract: 207 Penn faculty and staff signed an open letter urging administration to use the University's endowment to support graduate students and non-tenured faculty during the coronavirus pandemic.

filteredArticles.headline: Former dean of Penn School of Veterinary Medicine Barry Stupine dies at 78
filteredArticles.abstract: Stupine worked as an Associate Dean and then Vice Dean for Administration and Finance at Penn Vet from 1978 to 2009. He also held interim positions at the School of Dental Medicine and Office of Budget and Resources at Penn.

dominantMedia.content: Barry Stupine was the former leader of the School of Veterinary Medicine and Ryan Veterinary Hospital. (Photo from the Stupine Family)

filteredArticles.headline: Virtual commencement honors Class of 2020 after tumultuous spring semester
filteredArticles.abstract: Penn President Amy Gutmann was joined by commencement speaker and award-winning author Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, as well as 1999 College graduate and Grammy-award winning musician John Legend, to congratulate the Class of 2020.

filteredArticles.headline: Disillusioned students consider gap semesters if fall courses are held online
filteredArticles.abstract: University administration said they have no plans to amend the current leave of absence policy for the fall semester.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn considers combination of virtual and in-person classes for fall 2020
filteredArticles.abstract: Penn President Amy Gutmann wrote in an email to the Penn community on Monday that the University has established a Recovery Planning Group to determine when students will be able to return to campus.

filteredArticles.headline: Penn students can now opt in to pass/fail grading for all courses. Here’s what that means.

dominantMedia.content: Courses taken with pass/fail grading will count toward any major or general education requirements.
